Title:
Two new species of Phanerochaete on fallen angiosperm
branches from southern China
Keywords:
Corticioid fungi, Diversity, Hyphodermataceae, Molecular
phylogeny, Taxonomy, Yunnan Province
Abstract:
Two new wood-inhabiting fungal species, Phanerochaete
pruinosa and P. rhizomorpha spp. nov. are proposed based on a
combination of morphological features and molecular evidence.
Phanerochaete pruinosa is characterized by effused, basidiomata with
smooth to flocculent hymenial surface, a monomitic hyphal system with
clamped generative hyphae, IKI, CB and ellipsoid basidiospores measuring
as 3.436.99 × 1.502.93 µm. Hyphoderma tenuissimum is characterized by
resupinate basidiomata with tuberculate to minutely-grandinioid hymenial
surface, presence of septate cystidia and cylindrical to allantoid
basidiospores. Sequences of ITS+28S nrRNA gene regions of the studied
samples were generated and phylogenetic analyses were performed with
maximum likelihood, maximum parsimony and Bayesian inference methods.
These phylogenetic showed that the two new species clustered into
Hyphoderma, in which H. puerense grouped with H. moniliforme, and H.
tenuissimum was sister to H. mopanshanense.
